hints_html: Note the mention of rates of change - this will be a related rates problem. Before you differentiate, make sure you know which values in the given equation are constants and which are variables.
hints_latex:
Note the mention of rates of change - this will be a related rates
problem. Before you differentiate, make sure you know which values in
the given equation are constants and which are variables.
hints_raw: Note the mention of rates of change - this will be a related rates problem.  Before you differentiate, make sure you know which values in the given equation are constants and which are variables.
sols_html:
The question is asking us for the rate at which strain is increasing. Since strain is indicated by the variable \(\epsilon\), this means we are seeking \(\frac{d\epsilon}{dt}\).

To find \(\frac{d\epsilon}{dt}\) we differentiate the given formula with respect to t. Remember that a, b and n are constants, while \(\epsilon\) and \(\sigma\) are variables that depend on t. So \(\displaystyle \epsilon(t) = a \sigma(t) + b(\sigma(t))^n\) becomes

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d\epsilon}{dt}(t) = a \frac{d\sigma}{dt}(t) + bn (\sigma(t))^{n-1}\frac{d\sigma}{dt}(t)\end{aligned}\]

We were asked to find \(\frac{d\epsilon}{dt}\) where \(\sigma(t) = \sigma_0\), so we can plug that value into the expression above. Finally, recall we are also told earlier in the problem that the stress is increasing at a constant rate R. In the expression above, the rate of stress increasing is given by \(\frac{d\sigma}{dt}(t)\), so we replace \(\frac{d\sigma}{dt}(t)\) with R. This gives our final answer of:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d\epsilon}{dt} = a R + bn \sigma_0^{n-1}R\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
The question is asking us for the rate at which strain is increasing.
Since strain is indicated by the variable $\epsilon$, this means we are
seeking $\frac{d\epsilon}{dt}$.

To find $\frac{d\epsilon}{dt}$ we differentiate the given formula with
respect to \emph{t}. Remember that \emph{a}, \emph{b} and \emph{n} are
constants, while $\epsilon$ and $\sigma$ are variables that depend on
\emph{t}. So $\displaystyle \epsilon(t) = a \sigma(t) + b(\sigma(t))^n$
becomes

\begin{align*}
\frac{d\epsilon}{dt}(t) = a \frac{d\sigma}{dt}(t) + bn (\sigma(t))^{n-1}\frac{d\sigma}{dt}(t)
\end{align*}

We were asked to find $\frac{d\epsilon}{dt}$ where
$\sigma(t) = \sigma_0$, so we can plug that value into the expression
above. Finally, recall we are also told earlier in the problem that the
stress is increasing at a constant rate \emph{R}. In the expression
above, the rate of stress increasing is given by
$\frac{d\sigma}{dt}(t)$, so we replace $\frac{d\sigma}{dt}(t)$ with
\emph{R}. This gives our final answer of:

\begin{align*}
\frac{d\epsilon}{dt} = a R + bn \sigma_0^{n-1}R
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
The question is asking us for the rate at which strain is increasing.  Since strain is indicated by the variable <math>\epsilon</math>, this means we are seeking <math>\frac{d\epsilon}{dt}</math>.  

To find <math>\frac{d\epsilon}{dt}</math> we differentiate the given formula with respect to ''t''.  Remember that ''a'', ''b'' and ''n'' are constants, while <math>\epsilon</math> and <math>\sigma</math> are variables that depend on ''t''.  So <math> \displaystyle \epsilon(t) = a \sigma(t) + b(\sigma(t))^n </math> becomes

:<math>\frac{d\epsilon}{dt}(t) = a \frac{d\sigma}{dt}(t) + bn (\sigma(t))^{n-1}\frac{d\sigma}{dt}(t)</math>

We were asked to find <math>\frac{d\epsilon}{dt}</math> where <math>\sigma(t) = \sigma_0</math>, so we can plug that value into the expression above.  Finally, recall we are also told earlier in the problem that the stress is increasing at a constant rate ''R''.  In the expression above, the rate of stress increasing is given by <math>\frac{d\sigma}{dt}(t)</math>, so we replace <math>\frac{d\sigma}{dt}(t)</math> with ''R''.  This gives our final answer of:

:<math>\frac{d\epsilon}{dt} = a R + bn \sigma_0^{n-1}R</math>
statement_html:
In mechanics, a force exerted on a steel rod is called stress, and denoted by σ. The deformation of the rod due to this stress is called strain, and denoted \(\varepsilon\). Stress and strain are related by the Ramberg-Osgood equation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \epsilon = a \sigma + b\sigma^n\end{aligned}\]

where a, b and n are constants.

Suppose the stress applied to a steel rod increases at a constant rate of R. Determine the rate at which the strain is increasing when the stress is equal to σ0.

Hint: your answer will be an expression involving several constants.
statement_latex:
In mechanics, a force exerted on a steel rod is called \emph{stress},
and denoted by \emph{σ}. The deformation of the rod due to this stress
is called \emph{strain}, and denoted \emph{$\varepsilon$}. Stress and strain are
related by the
{Ramberg-Osgood
equation}

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
\epsilon = a \sigma + b\sigma^n
\end{align*}

where \emph{a}, \emph{b} and \emph{n} are constants.

Suppose the stress applied to a steel rod increases at a constant rate
of \emph{R}. Determine the rate at which the strain is increasing when
the stress is equal to \emph{σ\textsubscript{0}}.

\emph{Hint: your answer will be an expression involving several
constants.}
statement_raw:
In mechanics, a force exerted on a steel rod is called ''stress'', and denoted by ''&sigma;''. The deformation of the rod due to this stress is called ''strain'', and denoted ''&epsilon;''. Stress and strain are related by the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramberg%E2%80%93Osgood_relationship Ramberg-Osgood equation]

:<math> \displaystyle
\epsilon = a \sigma + b\sigma^n
</math>

where ''a'', ''b'' and ''n'' are constants.

Suppose the stress applied to a steel rod increases at a constant rate of ''R''. Determine the rate at which the strain is increasing when the stress is equal to ''&sigma;<sub>0</sub>''.

''Hint: your answer will be an expression involving several constants.''
